name: 3,5-dichlorophenol
Reason: 3,5-dichlorophenol has a melting point that we can compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of a chlorine atom, which introduces a strong withdrawing group that can increase the melting point by approximately +50°C. Additionally, the phenol group can contribute to the melting point due to its ability to form hydrogen bonds, estimated at around +20°C.
